title: 1034-B
statement: B. Little C Loves 3 IItime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputLittle C loves number «3» very much. He loves all things about it.Now he is playing a game on a chessboard of size $$$n \\times m$$$. The cell in the $$$x$$$-th row and in the $$$y$$$-th column is called $$$(x,y)$$$. Initially, The chessboard is empty. Each time, he places two chessmen on two different empty cells, the Manhattan distance between which is exactly $$$3$$$. The Manhattan distance between two cells $$$(x_i,y_i)$$$ and $$$(x_j,y_j)$$$ is defined as $$$|x_i-x_j|+|y_i-y_j|$$$.He want to place as many chessmen as possible on the chessboard. Please help him find the maximum number of chessmen he can place.InputA single line contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$m$$$ ($$$1 \\leq n,m \\leq 10^9$$$) — the number of rows and the number of columns of the chessboard.OutputPrint one integer — the maximum number of chessmen Little C can place.ExamplesInput2 2Output0Input3 3Output8NoteIn the first example, the Manhattan distance between any two cells is smaller than $$$3$$$, so the answer is $$$0$$$.In the second example, a possible solution is $$$(1,1)(3,2)$$$, $$$(1,2)(3,3)$$$, $$$(2,1)(1,3)$$$, $$$(3,1)(2,3)$$$.

You are given a chessboard of size $n \times m$.  You can place chess pieces on the board, with the following rule:

*  You can only place two chess pieces at a time.
*  The two pieces must be in different empty cells.
*  The Manhattan distance between the two placed pieces must be exactly 3.  The Manhattan distance between two cells $(x_i, y_i)$ and $(x_j, y_j)$ is defined as $|x_i - x_j| + |y_i - y_j|$.

Find the maximum number of chess pieces you can place on the board.

You have a grid of a given size. You can place pieces on the grid, but each piece must be placed 3 units away from any other piece (horizontally or vertically). Find the maximum number of pieces you can place.
